resources.string: Set at the foot of the Manhattan Bridge in Chinatown, this hip hotel with a midcentury-modern vibe...

Set at the foot of the Manhattan Bridge in Chinatown, this hip hotel with a midcentury-modern vibe is a 3-minute walk from the Grand Street subway station and an 8-minute walk from the Museum Of Chinese In America. Sleek, contemporary rooms offer complimentary Wi-Fi, iPod docks and flat-screen TVs, in addition to Keurig coffeemakers. Upgraded rooms and 1-bedroom suites add bridge or city views. Off-site parking is available for a fee.
Hotel Mimosa is located in the East Side neighborhood in New York City, just one mile from Ground Zero...

Hotel Mimosa is located in the East Side neighborhood in New York City, just one mile from Ground Zero. All rooms include a flat-screen TV. The rooms have a private bathroom fitted with a bathtub or shower. Extras include free toiletries and a hairdryer. You will find a 24-hour front desk at the property. One World Trade Center is one mile from Hotel Mimosa, and National September 11 Memorial & Museum is 1.1 miles from the property. The nearest airport is LaGuardia Airport, 7 miles from Hotel Mimosa.
Relax in beautifully designed guest rooms and suites with contemporary furnishings, private balconies and floor to ceiling windows with stunning views of the city...

Relax in beautifully designed guest rooms and suites with contemporary furnishings, private balconies and floor to ceiling windows with stunning views of the city. Savor seasonal American cuisine at the Wu Room. A recipient of the TripAdvisor Certificate of Excellence, our modern Manhattan hotel features intimate event space, complimentary Wi-Fi, and a dynamic ambiance where you can meet, lounge and dine in the beautiful Big Apple. Located in an eclectic Lower Manhattan neighborhood, it\'s easy to explore local nightlife, walk to the trendy shops of SoHo, and dine in Little Italy.
Overlooking Columbus Park, this contemporary Chinatown hotel is 0.3 miles from Little Italy and a 5-minute walk from the nearest subway station...

Overlooking Columbus Park, this contemporary Chinatown hotel is 0.3 miles from Little Italy and a 5-minute walk from the nearest subway station. Casual rooms and suites are decorated in a neutral palette with custom furnishings and offer pillow-top mattresses, flat-screen TVs and minifridges; some include terraces and/or city views. High-speed Internet access is available. Perks include free continental breakfast daily, a business center and a modern lobby with seating areas. Several fine and casual dining options are within a block of the hotel.
Hotel 50 Bowery is located in the Chinatown neighborhood in New York City, just 0.9 miles from Ground Zero...

Hotel 50 Bowery is located in the Chinatown neighborhood in New York City, just 0.9 miles from Ground Zero. Guests can enjoy the on-site bar. Private parking is available on site.Each room at this hotel is air conditioned and has a flat-screen TV. Certain rooms have a sitting area for your convenience. A terrace or balcony are featured in certain rooms. The rooms have a private bathroom. For your comfort, you will find free toiletries and a hairdryer.You will find a 24-hour front desk at the property. One World Trade Center is 0.9 miles from Hotel 50 Bowery, and National September 11 Memorial & Museum is 0.9 miles away. The nearest airport is LaGuardia Airport, 7 miles from Hotel 50 Bowery.
Located in downtown Manhattan, this hotel is steps from Little Italy and 400 feet from the Grand Street Subway station...

Located in downtown Manhattan, this hotel is steps from Little Italy and 400 feet from the Grand Street Subway station. It features guest rooms with flat-screen TVs and free Wi-Fi. Every room at the Best Western Bowery Hanbee Hotel provides coffee facilities. Each includes cable TV with in-room movies and a variety of international TV channels. A gym and a business center are available at the hotel. Bowery Hanbee Best Western Hotel also offers laundry facilities and a 24-hour front desk. Bowery Hanbee Hotel is within walking distance of the fabulous shopping of SoHo and the vibrant Chinatown area. Ground Zero is one mile away.
In Manhattan’s Lower East Side, Hotel 91 is a 5-minute walk from Chinatown and the East Broadway subway station...

In Manhattan’s Lower East Side, Hotel 91 is a 5-minute walk from Chinatown and the East Broadway subway station. It offers free wired internet and rooms with flat-screen cable TVs. Guest rooms include desks, hairdryers and alarm clock radios. A wakeup service is available. Hotel 91 offers a 24-hour front desk, ATM, and laundry facilities. Little Italy is a 10-minute walk from Hotel 91 while Ground Zero and South Street Seaport are 20 minutes away. Brooklyn Bridge and Wall Street are less than one mile away.
Located in the Bowery neighborhood in New York City, one mile from One World Trade Center, U.S. Pacific Hotel features...

Located in the Bowery neighborhood in New York City, one mile from One World Trade Center, U.S. Pacific Hotel features air-conditioned rooms with free WiFi throughout the property. Each room is fitted with a flat-screen TV. Ground Zero is one mile from U.S. Pacific Hotel, and National September 11 Memorial & Museum is one mile away. LaGuardia Airport is 7 miles from the property.
The Sun Bright hotel is in the center of Chinatown and one block from Grand Subway Station. The hotel offers
The Sun Bright hotel is in the center of Chinatown and one block from Grand Subway Station. The hotel offers Wi-Fi and a 24-hour front desk.
Sleep easy in a comfortable room. You can stay entertained with the free Wi-Fi, DVD player, an iPod docking station, and a...

Sleep easy in a comfortable room. You can stay entertained with the free Wi-Fi, DVD player, an iPod docking station, and a flat screen HDTV with over 200 premium channels. If you need to get some work done, take advantage of the work desk and lamp in your room. In the morning, make yourself one of the assorted coffees with the in-room coffee maker.
Whether you\'re traveling for business or pleasure, New World Hotel offers a variety of room types to ensure comfort for your needs at low prices...

Whether you\'re traveling for business or pleasure, New World Hotel offers a variety of room types to ensure comfort for your needs at low prices. Located at the heart of Chinatown, on Bowery, between Hester St. and Grand Street. New World Hotel puts the treasures of Chinatown at your fingertips. Special foods, items, and shops can be found on Canal Street, Mott Street, and Grand Street.
Boasting a shared lounge, Canal Loft Hotel is situated in New York in the New York State region, an 11-minute walk from Bloomingdales...

Boasting a shared lounge, Canal Loft Hotel is situated in New York in the New York State region, an 11-minute walk from Bloomingdales. Around 1.2 km from Brooklyn Bridge, the property is also 1.6 km away from Ground Zero and offers free WiFi. The property is a 20-minute walk from One World Trade Center.
Windsor Hotels offer affordable and spacious rooms, each adored with modern amenities and decor. Little Italy is conveniently located...

Windsor Hotels offer affordable and spacious rooms, each adored with modern amenities and decor. Little Italy is conveniently located within Chinatown and only a few hundred feet away from the hotel. This is also located minutes away from Wall Street, the SOHO District, and the gateway to the Statue of Liberty. In addition, convenient subway stations lead you to the glitter of Times Square, the glamour of the Theatre District, the famous Central Park, shopping at 5th Avenue, the events of Madison Square Garden, and the spirit of the Rockefeller Center.
Manhattan Bowery Lodge is situated in New York, 400 metres from Little Italy and 1.3 km from Brooklyn Bridge...

Manhattan Bowery Lodge is situated in New York, 400 metres from Little Italy and 1.3 km from Brooklyn Bridge.Manhattan Bowery Lodge features free WiFi and a 24-hour front desk. One World Trade Center is 1.5 km away, while Ground Zero is 1.6 km from the property. The nearest airport is LaGuardia Airport, 12 km from the property.
The Comfort Inn Lower East Side is perfectly located in the heart of Manhattan and is one of the newly built hotels in the area...

The Comfort Inn Lower East Side is perfectly located in the heart of Manhattan and is one of the newly built hotels in the area. The subway station is only a short block away, putting guests within walking distance from downtown, Wall Street and popular New York City hotspots like South Street Seaport, The World Trade Center, Little Italy and the Brooklyn Bridge Park and much more!
Devoted to presenting and preserving the history, heritage, and culture of Chinese immigrants in the US
NYC\'s largest Buddhist temple; provides services such as formal ceremonies on weekends, fortune telling, weddings, and areas for friends and families of the deceased to pay their respects
an Asian snack paradise for those wishing to satisfy their sweet tooth; sells a variety of dried foods, exotic hard-to-find savory treats, and nostalgic Western treats
A bar inspired by European apothecaries and resembles a chemistry lab; offers over 250 cocktails, referred to as "prescriptions"
At the heart of Chinatown; has a basketball court, playground, Astroturf field; The north is an area for mah-jongg and card players
Founded to serve and protect the interests of the Chinese people in the New York metropolitan area; provides social services, language classes and cultural preservation activities
An occult shop which specializes in feng shui, crystals, and horoscopes; the only place in the city that photographs and reads auras
A modern natural history museum located in a freight elevator; collection of unique artifacts
Located on the second floor of an apartment building this small but lively bar encourages patrons to belt out to the classics while drinking brews on tap
spend a day of relaxation and unwinding; provides spa and beauty services for face and body

From the 1840’s through 1920’s, learn about the earlier era of street gangs of NYC and about the evolution from small packs of immigrant thugs with tightly knit loyalties to an evolved, corporate style American syndicate. Mulberry Street, from Chinatown to Little Italy, is where most of the notorious gangsters in New York rose up. From the former Five Points, New York’s most notorious slum, to the narrow alleys Chinatown’s “Bloody Angle.” In Little Italy’s Historic District we learn the ruthless tactics of the first Mafia bosses of New York, the proud efforts of NYPD Liutenant Joe Petrosino’s fight against these thugs. Organized Crime as we know it was born on these streets.
meets at the corner of Mulberry & Worth streets
serves the Irish, German, Italian and, most recently, Chinese communities; Sunday masses are held in English, Mandarin, and Cantonese; houses a chinese school
an annual celebration of the beginning of the turn of the Chinese lunisolar calendar; features all kinds of vendors, festivities, and food for all ages
East Houston Street to Canal Street

an annual celebration of the end of the autumn harvest; held on the 15th day of the 8th lunar month; features stage performances, cultural arts & crafts, calligraphy, gift booths, moon cake tastings, etc.
Mott Street; between Canal and Beyard Streets
No-frills stalwart stocking a variety of home goods & Asian decor, from teapots to small furniture.
Address: 78 Mulberry St, New York, NY 10013
T-Pop Shop is a trendsetting Online Second Hand Clothing Store, offering first-rate products and exceptional customer service to shoppers from the comfort of their own homes
Address: 59 Franklin St, New York, NY 10013
If you need flowers arrangements, this is the place to go! Reasonably priced, and beautiful selections to choose from!
An excellent selection and display of various chopsticks. The selections range from simple children\'s, to elegant formal chopsticks.
An occult shop which specializes in feng shui, crystals, and horoscopes; the only place in the city that photographs and reads auras
Eclectic emporium with 3-floors of Chinese apparel, accessories, housewares & furniture.

" Come here for cute and cheap toys! So much product and easy to get lost in because of extremely cheap prices. Small stuffed animals (rilakkuma, doraemon, Totoro, Pokémon, etc) ranging from $3 to $5 "
An open-street shopping experience with an open-air bazaar feel, complete with vendors willing to bargain

The Mahayana Buddhist Temple is free, open to the public and offers a large meditation area with plenty of space to rest and reflect under the gaze of a 16-foot-high golden Buddha. Just don\'t expect silence here; there\'s usually a festive sound track playing (this is New York City, after all). While the giant Buddha is the temple\'s main attraction, don\'t miss the series of intricate ivory carvings on display in the second-floor gift shop (none are for sale).

The Museum promotes dialogue and understanding among people of all cultural backgrounds, bringing 160 years of Chinese American history to vivid life through its innovative exhibitions, educational and cultural programs.

Five Points (or The Five Points) was a 19th-century neighborhood in Lower Manhattan, New York City. The neighborhood was generally defined as being bound by Centre Street to the west, the Bowery to the east, Canal Street to the north, and Park Row to the south.

Five Points (or The Five Points) was a 19th-century neighborhood in Lower Manhattan, New York City. The neighborhood was generally defined as being bound by Centre Street to the west, the Bowery to the east, Canal Street to the north, and Park Row to the south.

The Jarmulowsky Bank Building is a 12-story building formerly housing the Jarmulowsky Bank on the Lower East Side of Manhattan, New York City. Located at Canal Street and Orchard Street, the Jarmulowsky Bank Building was built by architects Rouse & Goldstone in 1912, in Beaux-Arts style.

"The Edward Mooney House located at 18 Bowery at the corner of Pell Street in the Chinatown neighborhood of Manhattan, New York City was built between 1785 and 1789 for wealthy butcher Edward Mooney on land he purchased after it was confiscated from British Loyalist James De Lancey. "

The Pike Street Synagogue, constructed in 1903-04 for the. Congregation Sons of Israel Kalwarie, is a rare surviving synagogue building from that period of New York\'s history when the. Lower East Side served as America\'s main portal for millions of Jewish immigrants.

Columbus Park located in the heart of China Town is a great place to visit with the children and have a wonderful day. There is seating and swings with a safe area where the children could play. Most of the time you will run into musicians playing their music live.
16B Orchard Street (Canal Street) New York, NY 10002

The fantasies and confusion one may harbor about the eastern terminus of Canal Street are understandable because Chinatown is the crossroads where the city\'s past and future meet. Here remains one of the few Manhattan communities that fosters a sense of respect for its history.
No-frills place offering a big menu of beyond-the-basics Chinese dishes including soup dumplings. Phone Number: (212)766-6311
Vintage dim sum parlor dating back to 1920 with a drink menu that includes tea, beer and wine. Phone Number: (212) 962-6047
Salt-baked seafood, handmade noodles, soups and roast meat are served in a spartan setting. Phone Number: (212) 349-0923
Fish are plucked from tanks up front at this Cantonese seafood spot also known for a dim sum lunch. Phone Number: (212) 602-9988
Chinese noodles are made by hand and served in soups and stir-fries at this bustling, bare-bones spot. Phone Number: (212) 791-1817
Classic, long-running fast-food chain known for its burgers, fries and shakes. Phone Number: (212) 941- 5823
An Asian fast food restaurant that has cheap eats with lunch specials and can conveniently deliver right to your doorstep. Phone Number: (212) 925-5175
Hua Ji Pork Chop Fast Food
Tiny, modest Chinese counter-serve spot specializing in pork chops over rice and quick snacks. Phone Number: (212) 219-9876
Louisiana-accented fast-food chain known for its spicy fried chicken, biscuits and sides Phone Number: (212) 966-7077.

Straight from their website May Wah Fast Food specializes in soups, “over rice” dishes and noodle soups. Popular “over rice” dishes include their Chicken Leg Over Rice and Pork Chop Over Rice. Popular noodle soups include their Beef Noodle Soup and Shanghai Noodle Soup. Phone Number: (212) 925-6428
Cozy candy shop offering classic sweet treats plus nuts, dried fruit and house made chocolates. Phone Number: (212) 598-0092
A Japanese ice cream shop serving inventive flavors in a fish-shaped waffle cone. Phone Number: (212) 966-2882
Funky dessert cafe with creative shaved ice concoctions and waffles, plus craft coffee drinks and tea. Phone Number: (212) 226-8724
The Original Chinatown Ice Cream Factory
The flavors range from familiar to exotic (like lychee) at this compact ice-cream shop. Phone Number: (212) 608-4170
Chinese bakery for cakes, cookies and breads also offering hot and cold specialty drinks. Phone Number: (212) 791-3884
Trains: N, Q, R, W, J, Z, M, 4, 6
There are multiple way to get to the Canal Street subway station. It is a very large station that consists of many trains.
The only train that runs to East Broadway is the F train.
During the week ends the B trains do not run. Only the D trains stop at this station.
If you are in West Village, Flatiron District, Gramercy Park or East Village you can take the M14A bus that will take you into the Lower East Side into Chinatown.
Depending on where you are from Hudson Square to the Lower East Side, you can take the M21 bus to get across Manhattan.
You can take the M15 bus almost from anywhere in Manhattan. If you are in the west side of Manhattan you will have to walk east. This bus goes from Harlem to lower Manhattan.

Chinatown was created, after immigrants were driven out of the West due to anti-Chinese sentiments due to the fear of unemployment after the collapse of the Gold Rush and completion of the Transcontinental Railroad. Immigrants clustered into Pell, Mott, and Doyers Street and this eventually expanded to Chinatown as it is known today.

The Chinese Exclusion Act was established in 1882 due to anti-Chinese sentiments, which banned naturalization of the Chinese already in the US and the immigration of any Chinese person without a special work permit. This permit were for merchants, students, and merchants. The law also prohibited the wives and children of Chinese laborers from also entering the US. A group of merchants founded the Chinese Consolidated Benevolent Association, which served as an unofficial local government.
Pell and Mott streets become lined with Chinese restaurants. This attracted much attention from non-Chinese New Yorkers.

The gangs waged bloody battles in Chinatown, which made the residents and tourists afraid to walk the streets. Much of the warfare occured on Doyers Street. Chinese gangs controlled certain territories in Chinatown. The On Leong and affiliate Ghost Shadows controlled Mott, Bayard, Canal, and Mulberry streets. The Flying Dragons and affiliates Hip Sing controlled Doyers, Pell, Bowery, Grand, and Hester streets. The Tongs and the On Leong were gangs that most frequently fought.

Dr. Sun Yat Sen delivered a speech to Chinatown residents in 1911 at the Chinese Opera House. Dr. Sun Yat Sen was the first president of modern China and a Chinese Nationalist leader. The Chinese Opera House was bought by the CCBA (Chinese Consolidated Benevolent Association) and become the city hall of Chinatown.

The era of Prohibition began in the 1920s and ended in 1933. Gang wars had worsened and dozens of members were killed. Chinatown was raided by federal agents as an attempt to lower gang related crimes. Hundreds of residents were brought to the Federal Building and inspected. Those with their papers were released but, those without were sent to Ellis Island or to jail.

All around the world, countries were affected by the Great Depression. By 1931, 25% of Chinese Americans were unemployed and some turned to tongs for financial welfare. The spare money left over was sent back to China for defense after Japan invaded. This, along with many other factors, led to a decline in gang related crimes.

In the early 1950\'s, an urban renewal project threatened to remove Chinatown\'s historic core and replace it with businesses and residences in a large scale housing project. If the project, known as the China Village Plan, went through, it would have destroyed Chinatown\'s economy. Community advocates fought again this project until it was abandoned. Chinatown become the center of social activities for Chinese Americans. Two social clubs, known as the Jade Club and the Four Seas was formed in Chinatown.

World War II began. The Chinese Exclusion act was finally repealed in 1942, due to China allying with the US against Japan, and China was given a small quota of 105 immigrants annually. Many of them worked in restaurants, the garment industry, and hand washing business for less than minimum wage in awful conditions.

In 1965, the Immigration and Nationality Act abolished the Immigration Act of 1924, lifting the quota for Chinese immigrants. This led to a great immigration wave in Chinatown. The population exploded and caused Chinatown to grow and become more family oriented. Residents would take over parts of Little Italy by buying buildings and apartments to sell garments and goods.

Guangdong and Hong Kong immigrants began to develop newer parts of Chinatown north of Canal Street and east of Bowery. However, east of the Bowery was a very quiet section because many New Yorkers, especially Chinese Americans, were afraid to go there. This is due to deteriorating buildings and high crime rates.

Banks that opened new branches and renovated current ones in Chinatown began to use Chinese traditional styles for building facades. The Museum of Chinese in America was founded in 1980 to document the Chinese American experience.

During the 1990s the most important gangs were: the Chinese Ghost Shadows, Flying Dragons, Tung On, Fuk Ching, Green Dragons, White Tigers, Hung Ching, the Taiwan Brotherhood, and the Vietnamese Born-To-Kill gang. All these gangs were fighting for their piece of the city rackets and things got violent quickly and often.
Half of Chinatown was once part of the Five Points, an infamous slum. It was located between the Bowery, Park Row, Centre Street, and Canal Street
Canal Street was once, as the name implies, a canal. However, this canal was basically an open sewer and was a huge problem. It was filled in 1819 and a street in 1820.
The tallest Buddha Statue in New York is located at the Mahayana Buddhist Temple. It stands at 16 feet.
Excluding Asia, New York City has the largest Chinese population in a city.

Before 1965, Chinatown\'s population was overwhelmingly male. There was about 4,000 men to 20 married women! This is because entering the US after 1882 was almost impossible for the non-elite. Single and unemployed women weren\'t allowed to enter because they were viewed as prostititutes, who were banned in 1875.

Chinatown was a site of continuous gang activity in the early 1800s. A gang called the Tongs controlled underground trades of gambling and drug dealing. Business owners also relied on the Tongs to provide loans, legal aid, and protection from government interference. Many business owners lived in their stores, which violated codes.

Most of Old Chinatown has closed down due to changing immigration patterns, increased government presence, and relentless market forces. Most of Old Chinatown\'s businesses were closed due to brutal rent prices.
Mott Street is the oldest street in Chinatown inhabited by the Chinese people.
Doyers Street has appeared in many tv shows and movies, such as Person of Interest and The Amazing Spider-Man 2.
Chinatown Fair on Mott Street is one of the last remaining classic arcades in the world.
Emerge yourself in Chinatown\'s rich historical timeline!
List of Historical sights that you can explore!
Learn some fun facts about Chinatown!
